Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "More thorough investigation/fix for delayed download stats" (#5812) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Based on many personal experiences (including [today](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Flurl.Http/)), as well as GitHub issues, tweets, etc, the issue of delayed download stats seems like a chronic problem that's been going on for at least a year now. Even under "normal" circumstances (when it's not 19 hours behind like today) it seems like I have to wait quite a long time for those counts to update. Even at a huge scale of a billion packages, maintaining a reasonably current and stable counter associated with each of them doesn't seem like it would be that hard of a problem to solve.

I want to be as polite as possible here, and I don't think download stats are mission critical for anyone so I'm not suggesting this is red-hot, but isn't it possible there's a deeper architectural flaw or bottleneck, rather than some isolated incidents that are closed as soon as they appear to go away for the time being? In other words, would you consider investigating this from an architectural perspective rather than an operational one?

Thank you.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Transform Organization flow should link to the Email Confirmation flow if the user to transform has not yet confirmed their account" (#5477) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently, the transform to organization flow rejects accounts that have not yet been confirmed. It does not, however, link to the email confirmation page that allows you to resend the confirmation email in case it was never received. As a result, because the account settings page is blocked for users that have a discontinued login, unconfirmed users may find themselves stuck without the ability to transform into an organization and without the ability to confirm their email.

We should link to the email confirmation page in the transform to organization flow in case the user needs to resend their confirmation email.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuget support for mutual ssl authentication" (#6865) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: My organization wishes to create nuget packages for release to our internal feed provided by our TFS Server. The Department of Defense (DoD) relies heavily on the use of smartcards and CA certs and, like any DoD webserver, our TFS Server requires mutual ssl authentication. Unfortunately, we are unable to get past nuget issues on servers requiring SSL Client Certificates. Any help your team can provide towards resolving this issue would be greatly appreciated. Nuget support of windows certificate stores would be ideal.  Microsoft's TFS/VSTS teams plan to update their credential providers to support mutual SSL auth in coordination with your work.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet pack does not include runtime binaries when multiple targets are specified" (#6864) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Visual Studio 15.6.5
Package Manager Console Host Version 4.6.2.5055
Windows 10 1709

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a NETStandard class library and enable pack-on-build

2. Add a runtime binary (ex, native.dll, libnative.so)

3. Build and observe the binary is packed in the nupkg, within the `runtimes` folder

4. Add an additional target framework such as `net461` via the `<TargetFrameworks>` property

5. Build and observe that binary is no longer packed, and `runtimes` folder is missing entirely

### Sample Project

Sample project:
https://github.com/superstator/nugetrepro

As committed, the project will build and pack as expected.
Uncomment line [5 in  `TestLib.csproj`](https://github.com/superstator/nugetrepro/blob/826075ccbfe5102cd9544ebf6e0a22696807d935/TestLib/TestLib.csproj#L5) and runtimes are no longer included.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow empty replacement tokens in NuspecProperties " (#6722) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
When using `<NuspecProperties>` and `<NuspecFile>` in .csproj, I cannot use empty replacement tokens. This is important sometimes because metadata may not always be available, or I may want it empty.

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a project
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>netstandard2.0</TargetFramework>
    <NuspecFile>repro.nuspec</NuspecFile>
    <NuspecProperties>commithash=$(CommitHash)</NuspecProperties>
  </PropertyGroup>
</Project>
```
1. Create a nuspec like this:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<package xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/packaging/2012/06/nuspec.xsd">
  <metadata>
    <id>repro</id>
    <version>1.0.0</version>
    <authors>repro</authors>
    <description>Package from $commithash$</description>
    <dependencies />
    <repository type="git"
      url="http://github.com/NuGet"
      commit="$commithash$" />
  </metadata>
  <files>
    <file src="bin/Debug/netstandard2.0/repro.dll" target="lib/netstandard2.0/repro.dll" />
  </files>
</package>
```
2. `dotnet pack`

## Expected

Empty values in NuspecProperties are okay. Let nuspec validation decide when something is required or not.

## Actual

Pack fails with:

> /Users/namc/.dotnet/sdk/2.1.300-preview2-008367/Sdks/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack/build/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(198,5): error : NuspecProperties should be in the form of "key1=value1;key2=value2". [/private/tmp/repro/repro.csproj]


## Details
```
$ dotnet --version
2.1.300-preview2-008367
```

@rohit21agrawal

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PC to PR: default version range (All) no longer includes prerelease versions" (#6863) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
If a dependency .nuspec has an empty version range, the version range defaults to `(, )` (`VersionRange.All`).

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/d55be0be422845795dd6dab3ac95749fe8ede7ba/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Packaging.Core/PackageDependency.cs#L64

In a package.config project, this essentially means bring in the lowest version, prerelease or stable.

In a PackageReference project, this means bring in the lowest stable version.

This means that some dependencies stop working PackageReference.

## Steps to repro

1. Create a new .NET Framework console app project.
1. Install a working dependency, like `Newtonsoft.Json` and select `PackageReference` style.
1. Open package manager console.
1. `install-package CyberSource.Configuration.SqlClient-csharpapi -version 2012.8.23.3-pre`

```
install-package : NU1103: Unable to find a stable package CyberSource-csharpapi with version 
  - Found 18 version(s) in nuget.org [ Nearest version: 0.0.0.1-pre ]
  - Found 0 version(s) in Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages
```

There are no stable versions of `CyberSource-csharpapi` which means `(, )` is not satisfied.

I don't know how many packages on nuget.org have this problem.

## Expected outcome

This works just fine in packages.config. This is the resulting packages.config file:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<packages>
  <package id="CyberSource.Configuration.SqlClient-csharpapi" version="2012.8.23.3-pre" targetFramework="net461" />
  <package id="CyberSource-csharpapi" version="0.0.0.1-pre" targetFramework="net461" />
  <package id="Newtonsoft.Json" version="11.0.2" targetFramework="net461" />
</packages>
```

## Code bug or docs bug?

This is a change in behavior from packages.config but the XML docs on `VersionRange.All` suggest that this should work:

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/d55be0be422845795dd6dab3ac95749fe8ede7ba/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Versioning/VersionRangeFactory.cs#L16-L19
